description: From Middle English rinnen, from Old English rinnan (“to run”), from Proto-Germanic *rinnaną (“to run”). More at run.

verbs.description: rin (third-person singular simple present rins, present participle rinning, simple past ran, past participle run)

examples: "Besides," he continued, "I'm no sure that I'm right in rinning—rinning! I'm no rinning , I'm ganging; weel then I'm no sure that I'm right doing a witch's errand, whether rinning or ganging, sae I'se stand still and consider it. […] ."

entries.meaning: A coin worth 1⁄1000 of a Japanese yen, no longer in circulation.
